questions: How do facilities determine if they need to report emissions under Subpart W of the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Rule?
answers: Facilities are required to report under Subpart W if their annual emissions are more than 25,000 metric tons CO2e from all applicable sources at the facility.

questions: How does the API Compendium assist in estimating direct GHG emissions?
answers: The API Compendium details methodologies for the natural gas and oil industry segments to consistently estimate direct GHG emissions over the entire value chain.

questions: How will the ESRS E1 document's disclosures on climate-related opportunities help users?
answers: The ESRS E1 document's disclosures on climate-related opportunities will help users understand the nature of cost savings, time horizons, and how entities assess market size or expected changes to revenue from low-carbon products and services.

questions: How does the EPA plan to make the official version of the document available to the public?
answers: The EPA will publish the official version of the document on the Government Printing Office’s website and Regulations.gov.

questions: How does ASIC plan to support entities in complying with their sustainability reporting obligations?
answers: ASIC will support entities by explaining how it will exercise powers under legislation, how it interprets the law, and by providing practical guidance on complying with sustainability reporting obligations.

questions: Why is accuracy important in the data reported under the amended rule for petroleum and natural gas systems?
answers: Ensuring accuracy is important to make sure that reporting is based on empirical data, accurately reflects total methane emissions and waste emissions from applicable facilities, and allows owners and operators to submit empirical emissions data that appropriately demonstrate the extent to which those emissions are or are not waste.

questions: How does reporting under 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart W vary for onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities?
answers: Onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities must report emissions if their annual emissions are more than 25,000 metric tons CO2e from all applicable sources at the facility.

questions: How will the definition of low-carbon products and services be specified according to the ESRS E1 document?
answers: The definition of low-carbon products and services is expected to be specified in the future enhancement of the ESRS, potentially based on life-cycle GHG emissions savings or criteria for green products and services.

questions: How does the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) relate to the Waste Emissions Charge?
answers: The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) requires the EPA to impose and collect an annual charge on methane emissions.

questions: How do the new AASB standards compare to IFRS standards?
answers: The new AASB standards align with IFRS S1 General requirements for disclosure of sustainability-related financial information and IFRS S2 Climate-related disclosures.

questions: Why is the reporting of the individual components of blended feedstock important?
answers: Reporting the individual components of blended feedstock is necessary to meet the reporting requirements for products that enter the facility to be further refined or otherwise used on site.

questions: How does the EPA ensure that the reporting accurately reflects total methane emissions and waste emissions?
answers: The EPA is amending requirements to ensure that reporting is based on empirical data and accurately reflects total methane emissions and waste emissions from applicable facilities.

questions: Why is the reporting of climate-related financial risks and opportunities important?
answers: Reporting of climate-related financial risks and opportunities is important for providing Australians and investors with greater transparency and more comparable information.

questions: How does the EPA define the source category under 40 CFR Part 98 Subpart LL?
answers: This source category consists of producers, importers, and exporters of products listed in Table MM-1 of subpart MM that are coal-based (coal-to-liquid products).
